trans-unit.source: How to use Access Control (Java) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Access Control (Java) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to develop and use Access Control with Java in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to develop and use Access Control with Java in Azure.

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to use the Azure Access Control Service (ACS) within the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies).
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to use the Azure Access Control Service (ACS) within the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies).

trans-unit.source: For more information on ACS, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: For more information on ACS, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Access Services Control Filter (by Microsoft Open Technologies) is a community technology preview.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Access Services Control Filter (by Microsoft Open Technologies) is a community technology preview.

trans-unit.source: As pre-release software, it is not formally supported by Microsoft Open Technologies, Inc. nor Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: As pre-release software, it is not formally supported by Microsoft Open Technologies, Inc. nor Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: Most developers are not identity experts and generally do not want to spend time developing authentication and authorization mechanisms for their applications and services.
trans-unit.target: Most developers are not identity experts and generally do not want to spend time developing authentication and authorization mechanisms for their applications and services.

trans-unit.source: ACS is an Azure service that provides an easy way of authenticating users who need to access your web applications and services without having to factor complex authentication logic into your code.
trans-unit.target: ACS is an Azure service that provides an easy way of authenticating users who need to access your web applications and services without having to factor complex authentication logic into your code.

trans-unit.source: The following features are available in ACS:
trans-unit.target: The following features are available in ACS:

trans-unit.source: Integration with Windows Identity Foundation (WIF).
trans-unit.target: Integration with Windows Identity Foundation (WIF).

trans-unit.source: Support for popular web identity providers (IPs) including Windows Live ID, Google, Yahoo!, and Facebook.
trans-unit.target: Support for popular web identity providers (IPs) including Windows Live ID, Google, Yahoo!, and Facebook.

trans-unit.source: Support for Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) 2.0.
trans-unit.target: Support for Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) 2.0.

trans-unit.source: An Open Data Protocol (OData)-based management service that provides programmatic access to ACS settings.
trans-unit.target: An Open Data Protocol (OData)-based management service that provides programmatic access to ACS settings.

trans-unit.source: A Management Portal that allows administrative access to the ACS settings.
trans-unit.target: A Management Portal that allows administrative access to the ACS settings.

trans-unit.source: For more information about ACS, see <linkText>Access Control Service 2.0</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about ACS, see <linkText>Access Control Service 2.0</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure ACS is built on the principals of claims-based identity - a consistent approach to creating authentication mechanisms for applications running on-premises or in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Azure ACS is built on the principals of claims-based identity - a consistent approach to creating authentication mechanisms for applications running on-premises or in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Claims-based identity provides a common way for applications and services to acquire the identity information they need about users inside their organization, in other organizations, and on the Internet.
trans-unit.target: Claims-based identity provides a common way for applications and services to acquire the identity information they need about users inside their organization, in other organizations, and on the Internet.

trans-unit.source: To complete the tasks in this guide, you should understand the following concepts:
trans-unit.target: To complete the tasks in this guide, you should understand the following concepts:

trans-unit.source: Client - In the context of this how-to guide, this is a browser that is attempting to gain access to your web application.
trans-unit.target: Client - In the context of this how-to guide, this is a browser that is attempting to gain access to your web application.

trans-unit.source: Relying party (RP) application - An RP application is a website or service that outsources authentication to one external authority.
trans-unit.target: Relying party (RP) application - An RP application is a website or service that outsources authentication to one external authority.

trans-unit.source: In identity jargon, we say that the RP trusts that authority.
trans-unit.target: In identity jargon, we say that the RP trusts that authority.

trans-unit.source: This guide explains how to configure your application to trust ACS.
trans-unit.target: This guide explains how to configure your application to trust ACS.

trans-unit.source: Token - A token is a collection of security data that is usually issued upon successful authentication of a user.
trans-unit.target: Token - A token is a collection of security data that is usually issued upon successful authentication of a user.

trans-unit.source: It contains a set of claims, attributes of the authenticated user.
trans-unit.target: It contains a set of claims, attributes of the authenticated user.

trans-unit.source: A claim can represent a user's name, an identifier for a role a user belongs to, a user's age, and so on.
trans-unit.target: A claim can represent a user's name, an identifier for a role a user belongs to, a user's age, and so on.

trans-unit.source: A token is usually digitally signed, which means it can always be sourced back to its issuer, and its content cannot be tampered with.
trans-unit.target: A token is usually digitally signed, which means it can always be sourced back to its issuer, and its content cannot be tampered with.

trans-unit.source: A user gains access to a RP application by presenting a valid token issued by an authority that the RP application trusts.
trans-unit.target: A user gains access to a RP application by presenting a valid token issued by an authority that the RP application trusts.

trans-unit.source: Identity Provider (IP) - An IP is an authority that authenticates user identities and issues security tokens.
trans-unit.target: Identity Provider (IP) - An IP is an authority that authenticates user identities and issues security tokens.

trans-unit.source: The actual work of issuing tokens is implemented though a special service called Security Token Service (STS).
trans-unit.target: The actual work of issuing tokens is implemented though a special service called Security Token Service (STS).

trans-unit.source: Typical examples of IPs include Windows Live ID, Facebook, business user repositories (like Active Directory), and so on.
trans-unit.target: Typical examples of IPs include Windows Live ID, Facebook, business user repositories (like Active Directory), and so on.

trans-unit.source: When ACS is configured to trust an IP, the system will accept and validate tokens issued by that IP.
trans-unit.target: When ACS is configured to trust an IP, the system will accept and validate tokens issued by that IP.

trans-unit.source: ACS can trust multiple IPs at once, which means that when your application trusts ACS, you can instantly offer your application to all the authenticated users from all the IPs that ACS trusts on your behalf.
trans-unit.target: ACS can trust multiple IPs at once, which means that when your application trusts ACS, you can instantly offer your application to all the authenticated users from all the IPs that ACS trusts on your behalf.

trans-unit.source: Federation Provider (FP) - IPs have direct knowledge of users, and authenticate them using their credentials and issue claims about what they know about them.
trans-unit.target: Federation Provider (FP) - IPs have direct knowledge of users, and authenticate them using their credentials and issue claims about what they know about them.

trans-unit.source: A Federation Provider (FP) is a different kind of authority: rather than authenticating users directly, it acts as an intermediary and brokers authentication between one RP and one or more IPs.
trans-unit.target: A Federation Provider (FP) is a different kind of authority: rather than authenticating users directly, it acts as an intermediary and brokers authentication between one RP and one or more IPs.

trans-unit.source: Both IPs and FPs issue security tokens, hence they both use Security Token Services (STS).
trans-unit.target: Both IPs and FPs issue security tokens, hence they both use Security Token Services (STS).

trans-unit.source: ACS is one FP.
trans-unit.target: ACS is one FP.

trans-unit.source: ACS Rule Engine - The logic used to transform incoming tokens from trusted IPs to tokens meant to be consumed by the RP is codified in form of simple claims transformation rules.
trans-unit.target: ACS Rule Engine - The logic used to transform incoming tokens from trusted IPs to tokens meant to be consumed by the RP is codified in form of simple claims transformation rules.

trans-unit.source: ACS features a rule engine that takes care of applying whatever transformation logic you specified for your RP.
trans-unit.target: ACS features a rule engine that takes care of applying whatever transformation logic you specified for your RP.

trans-unit.source: ACS Namespace - A namespace is a top level partition of ACS that you use for organizing your settings.
trans-unit.target: ACS Namespace - A namespace is a top level partition of ACS that you use for organizing your settings.

trans-unit.source: A namespace holds a list of IPs you trust, the RP applications you want to serve, the rules that you expect the rule engine to process incoming tokens with, and so on.
trans-unit.target: A namespace holds a list of IPs you trust, the RP applications you want to serve, the rules that you expect the rule engine to process incoming tokens with, and so on.

trans-unit.source: A namespace exposes various endpoints that will be used by the application and the developer to get ACS to perform its function.
trans-unit.target: A namespace exposes various endpoints that will be used by the application and the developer to get ACS to perform its function.

trans-unit.source: The following figure shows how ACS authentication works with a web application:
trans-unit.target: The following figure shows how ACS authentication works with a web application:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>ACS flow diagram</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>ACS flow diagram</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The client (in this case a browser) requests a page from the RP.
trans-unit.target: The client (in this case a browser) requests a page from the RP.

trans-unit.source: Since the request is not yet authenticated, the RP redirects the user to the authority that it trusts, which is ACS.
trans-unit.target: Since the request is not yet authenticated, the RP redirects the user to the authority that it trusts, which is ACS.

trans-unit.source: The ACS presents the user with the choice of IPs that were specified for this RP.
trans-unit.target: The ACS presents the user with the choice of IPs that were specified for this RP.

trans-unit.source: The user selects the appropriate IP.
trans-unit.target: The user selects the appropriate IP.

trans-unit.source: The client browses to the IP's authentication page, and prompts the user to log on.
trans-unit.target: The client browses to the IP's authentication page, and prompts the user to log on.

trans-unit.source: After the client is authenticated (for example, the identity credentials are entered), the IP issues a security token.
trans-unit.target: After the client is authenticated (for example, the identity credentials are entered), the IP issues a security token.

trans-unit.source: After issuing a security token, the IP redirects the client to ACS and the client sends the security token issued by the IP to ACS.
trans-unit.target: After issuing a security token, the IP redirects the client to ACS and the client sends the security token issued by the IP to ACS.

trans-unit.source: ACS validates the security token issued by the IP, inputs the identity claims in this token into the ACS rules engine, calculates the output identity claims, and issues a new security token that contains these output claims.
trans-unit.target: ACS validates the security token issued by the IP, inputs the identity claims in this token into the ACS rules engine, calculates the output identity claims, and issues a new security token that contains these output claims.

trans-unit.source: ACS redirects the client to the RP.
trans-unit.target: ACS redirects the client to the RP.

trans-unit.source: The client sends the new security token issued by ACS to the RP.
trans-unit.target: The client sends the new security token issued by ACS to the RP.

trans-unit.source: The RP validates the signature on the security token issued by ACS, validates the claims in this token, and returns the page that was originally requested.
trans-unit.target: The RP validates the signature on the security token issued by ACS, validates the claims in this token, and returns the page that was originally requested.

trans-unit.source: To complete the tasks in this guide, you will need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete the tasks in this guide, you will need the following:

trans-unit.source: A Java Developer Kit (JDK), v 1.6 or later.
trans-unit.target: A Java Developer Kit (JDK), v 1.6 or later.

trans-unit.source: Eclipse IDE for Java EE Developers, Indigo or later. This can be downloaded from <http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/>.
trans-unit.target: Eclipse IDE for Java EE Developers, Indigo or later. This can be downloaded from <http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/>.

trans-unit.source: A distribution of a Java-based web server or application server, such as Apache Tomcat, GlassFish, JBoss Application Server, or Jetty.
trans-unit.target: A distribution of a Java-based web server or application server, such as Apache Tomcat, GlassFish, JBoss Application Server, or Jetty.

trans-unit.source: an Azure subscription, which can be acquired from <http://www.microsoft.com/windowsazure/offers/>.
trans-unit.target: an Azure subscription, which can be acquired from <http://www.microsoft.com/windowsazure/offers/>.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies), April 2014 release.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies), April 2014 release.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Installing the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Installing the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: An X.509 certificate to use with your application.
trans-unit.target: An X.509 certificate to use with your application.

trans-unit.source: You will need this certificate in both public certificate (.cer) and Personal Information Exchange (.PFX) format.
trans-unit.target: You will need this certificate in both public certificate (.cer) and Personal Information Exchange (.PFX) format.

trans-unit.source: (Options for creating this certificate will be described later in this tutorial).
trans-unit.target: (Options for creating this certificate will be described later in this tutorial).

trans-unit.source: Familiarity with the Azure compute emulator and deployment techniques discussed at <linkText>Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Familiarity with the Azure compute emulator and deployment techniques discussed at <linkText>Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To begin using Access Control Service (ACS) in Azure, you must create an ACS namespace.
trans-unit.target: To begin using Access Control Service (ACS) in Azure, you must create an ACS namespace.

trans-unit.source: The namespace provides a unique scope for addressing ACS resources from within your application.
trans-unit.target: The namespace provides a unique scope for addressing ACS resources from within your application.

trans-unit.source: Log into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Log into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Click Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: To create a new Access Control namespace, click New, click App Services, click Access Control, and then click Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: To create a new Access Control namespace, click New, click App Services, click Access Control, and then click Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the namespace.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the namespace.

trans-unit.source: Azure verifies that the name is unique.
trans-unit.target: Azure verifies that the name is unique.

trans-unit.source: Select the region in which the namespace is used.
trans-unit.target: Select the region in which the namespace is used.

trans-unit.source: For the best performance, use the region in which you are deploying your application.
trans-unit.target: For the best performance, use the region in which you are deploying your application.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one subscription, select the subscription that you want to use for the ACS namespace.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one subscription, select the subscription that you want to use for the ACS namespace.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: Azure creates and activates the namespace.
trans-unit.target: Azure creates and activates the namespace.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the status of the new namespace is Active before continuing.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the status of the new namespace is Active before continuing.

trans-unit.source: In this task, you add IPs to use with your RP application for authentication.
trans-unit.target: In this task, you add IPs to use with your RP application for authentication.

trans-unit.source: For demonstration purposes, this task shows how to add Windows Live as an IP, but you could use any of the IPs listed in the ACS Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: For demonstration purposes, this task shows how to add Windows Live as an IP, but you could use any of the IPs listed in the ACS Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, click Active Directory, select an Access Control namespace, and then click Manage.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, click Active Directory, select an Access Control namespace, and then click Manage.

trans-unit.source: The ACS Management Portal opens.
trans-unit.target: The ACS Management Portal opens.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation pane of the ACS Management Portal, click Identity providers.
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation pane of the ACS Management Portal, click Identity providers.

trans-unit.source: Windows Live ID is enabled by default, and cannot be deleted.
trans-unit.target: Windows Live ID is enabled by default, and cannot be deleted.

trans-unit.source: For purposes of this tutorial, only Windows Live ID is used.
trans-unit.target: For purposes of this tutorial, only Windows Live ID is used.

trans-unit.source: This screen, however, is where you could add other IPs, by clicking the Add button.
trans-unit.target: This screen, however, is where you could add other IPs, by clicking the Add button.

trans-unit.source: Windows Live ID is now enabled as an IP for your ACS namespace.
trans-unit.target: Windows Live ID is now enabled as an IP for your ACS namespace.

trans-unit.source: Next, you specify your Java web application (to be created later) as an RP.
trans-unit.target: Next, you specify your Java web application (to be created later) as an RP.

trans-unit.source: In this task, you configure ACS to recognize your Java web application as a valid RP application.
trans-unit.target: In this task, you configure ACS to recognize your Java web application as a valid RP application.

trans-unit.source: On the ACS Management Portal, click Relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: On the ACS Management Portal, click Relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: On the Relying Party Applications page, click Add.
trans-unit.target: On the Relying Party Applications page, click Add.

trans-unit.source: On the Add Relying Party Application page, do the following:
trans-unit.target: On the Add Relying Party Application page, do the following:

trans-unit.source: In Name, type the name of the RP.
trans-unit.target: In Name, type the name of the RP.

trans-unit.source: For purposes of this tutorial, type Azure Web App.
trans-unit.target: For purposes of this tutorial, type Azure Web App.

trans-unit.source: In Mode, select Enter settings manually.
trans-unit.target: In Mode, select Enter settings manually.

trans-unit.source: In Realm, type the URI to which the security token issued by ACS applies.
trans-unit.target: In Realm, type the URI to which the security token issued by ACS applies.

trans-unit.source: For this task, type http://localhost:8080/.
trans-unit.target: For this task, type http://localhost:8080/.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Relying party realm for use in compute emulator</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Relying party realm for use in compute emulator</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In Return URL, type the URL to which ACS returns the security token.
trans-unit.target: In Return URL, type the URL to which ACS returns the security token.

trans-unit.source: For this task, type http://localhost:8080/MyACSHelloWorld/index.jsp Relying party return URL for use in compute emulator
trans-unit.target: For this task, type http://localhost:8080/MyACSHelloWorld/index.jsp Relying party return URL for use in compute emulator

trans-unit.source: Accept the default values in the rest of the fields.
trans-unit.target: Accept the default values in the rest of the fields.

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: You have now successfully configured your Java web application when it is run in the Azure compute emulator (at http://localhost:8080/) to be an RP in your ACS namespace.
trans-unit.target: You have now successfully configured your Java web application when it is run in the Azure compute emulator (at http://localhost:8080/) to be an RP in your ACS namespace.

trans-unit.source: Next, create the rules that ACS uses to process claims for the RP.
trans-unit.target: Next, create the rules that ACS uses to process claims for the RP.

trans-unit.source: In this task, you define the rules that drive how claims are passed from IPs to your RP.
trans-unit.target: In this task, you define the rules that drive how claims are passed from IPs to your RP.

trans-unit.source: For the purpose of this guide, we will simply configure ACS to copy the input claim types and values directly in the output token, without filtering or modifying them.
trans-unit.target: For the purpose of this guide, we will simply configure ACS to copy the input claim types and values directly in the output token, without filtering or modifying them.

trans-unit.source: On the ACS Management Portal main page, click Rule groups.
trans-unit.target: On the ACS Management Portal main page, click Rule groups.

trans-unit.source: On the Rule Groups page, click Default Rule Group for Azure Web App.
trans-unit.target: On the Rule Groups page, click Default Rule Group for Azure Web App.

trans-unit.source: On the Edit Rule Group page, click Generate.
trans-unit.target: On the Edit Rule Group page, click Generate.

trans-unit.source: On the Generate Rules: Default Rule Group for Azure Web App page, ensure Windows Live ID is checked and then click Generate.
trans-unit.target: On the Generate Rules: Default Rule Group for Azure Web App page, ensure Windows Live ID is checked and then click Generate.

trans-unit.source: On the Edit Rule Group page, click Save.
trans-unit.target: On the Edit Rule Group page, click Save.

trans-unit.source: In this task, you upload a .PFX certificate that will be used to sign token requests created by your ACS namespace.
trans-unit.target: In this task, you upload a .PFX certificate that will be used to sign token requests created by your ACS namespace.

trans-unit.source: On the ACS Management Portal main page, click Certificates and keys.
trans-unit.target: On the ACS Management Portal main page, click Certificates and keys.

trans-unit.source: On the Certificates and Keys page, click Add above Token Signing.
trans-unit.target: On the Certificates and Keys page, click Add above Token Signing.

trans-unit.source: On the Add Token-Signing Certificate or Key page:
trans-unit.target: On the Add Token-Signing Certificate or Key page:

trans-unit.source: In the Used for section, click Relying Party Application and select Azure Web App (which you previously set as the name of your relying party application).
trans-unit.target: In the Used for section, click Relying Party Application and select Azure Web App (which you previously set as the name of your relying party application).

trans-unit.source: In the Type section, select X.509 Certificate.
trans-unit.target: In the Type section, select X.509 Certificate.

trans-unit.source: In the Certificate section, click the browse button and navigate to the X.509 certificate file that you want to use.
trans-unit.target: In the Certificate section, click the browse button and navigate to the X.509 certificate file that you want to use.

trans-unit.source: This will be a .PFX file.
trans-unit.target: This will be a .PFX file.

trans-unit.source: Select the file, click Open, and then enter the certificate password in the Password text box.
trans-unit.target: Select the file, click Open, and then enter the certificate password in the Password text box.

trans-unit.source: Note that for testing purposes, you may use a self-signed-certificate.
trans-unit.target: Note that for testing purposes, you may use a self-signed-certificate.

trans-unit.source: To create a self-signed certificate, use the New button in the ACS Filter Library dialog (described later), or use the encutil.exe utility from the project website of the Azure Starter Kit for Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies).
trans-unit.target: To create a self-signed certificate, use the New button in the ACS Filter Library dialog (described later), or use the encutil.exe utility from the project website of the Azure Starter Kit for Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies).

trans-unit.source: Ensure that Make Primary is checked.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that Make Primary is checked.

trans-unit.source: Your Add Token-Signing Certificate or Key page should look similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: Your Add Token-Signing Certificate or Key page should look similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add token-signing certificate</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add token-signing certificate</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Save to save your settings and close the Add Token-Signing Certificate or Key page.
trans-unit.target: Click Save to save your settings and close the Add Token-Signing Certificate or Key page.

trans-unit.source: Next, review the information in the Application Integration page and copy the URI that you will need to configure your Java web application to use ACS.
trans-unit.target: Next, review the information in the Application Integration page and copy the URI that you will need to configure your Java web application to use ACS.

trans-unit.source: You can find all the information and the code necessary to configure your Java web application (the RP application) to work with ACS on the Application Integration page of the ACS Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: You can find all the information and the code necessary to configure your Java web application (the RP application) to work with ACS on the Application Integration page of the ACS Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: You will need this information when configuring your Java web application for federated authentication.
trans-unit.target: You will need this information when configuring your Java web application for federated authentication.

trans-unit.source: On the ACS Management Portal, click Application integration.
trans-unit.target: On the ACS Management Portal, click Application integration.

trans-unit.source: In the Application Integration page, click Login Pages.
trans-unit.target: In the Application Integration page, click Login Pages.

trans-unit.source: In the Login Page Integration page, click Azure Web App.
trans-unit.target: In the Login Page Integration page, click Azure Web App.

trans-unit.source: In the Login Page Integration: Azure Web App page, the URL listed in Option 1: Link to an ACS-hosted login page will be used in your Java web application.
trans-unit.target: In the Login Page Integration: Azure Web App page, the URL listed in Option 1: Link to an ACS-hosted login page will be used in your Java web application.

trans-unit.source: You will need this value when you add the Azure Access Control Services Filter library to your Java application.
trans-unit.target: You will need this value when you add the Azure Access Control Services Filter library to your Java application.

trans-unit.source: Within Eclipse, at the menu click File, click New, and then click Dynamic Web Project.
trans-unit.target: Within Eclipse, at the menu click File, click New, and then click Dynamic Web Project.

trans-unit.source: (If you don't see Dynamic Web Project listed as an available project after clicking File, New, then do the following: click File, click New, click Project, expand Web, click Dynamic Web Project, and click Next.)
trans-unit.target: (If you don't see Dynamic Web Project listed as an available project after clicking File, New, then do the following: click File, click New, click Project, expand Web, click Dynamic Web Project, and click Next.)

trans-unit.source: For purposes of this tutorial, name the project MyACSHelloWorld.
trans-unit.target: For purposes of this tutorial, name the project MyACSHelloWorld.

trans-unit.source: (Ensure you use this name, subsequent steps in this tutorial expect your WAR file to be named MyACSHelloWorld).
trans-unit.target: (Ensure you use this name, subsequent steps in this tutorial expect your WAR file to be named MyACSHelloWorld).

trans-unit.source: Your screen will appear similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: Your screen will appear similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a Hello World project for ACS exampple</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a Hello World project for ACS exampple</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Within Eclipse's Project Explorer view, expand MyACSHelloWorld.
trans-unit.target: Within Eclipse's Project Explorer view, expand MyACSHelloWorld.

trans-unit.source: Right-click WebContent, click New, and then click JSP File.
trans-unit.target: Right-click WebContent, click New, and then click JSP File.

trans-unit.source: In the New JSP File dialog, name the file index.jsp.
trans-unit.target: In the New JSP File dialog, name the file index.jsp.

trans-unit.source: Keep the parent folder as MyACSHelloWorld/WebContent, as shown in the following:
trans-unit.target: Keep the parent folder as MyACSHelloWorld/WebContent, as shown in the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add a JSP file for ACS example</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add a JSP file for ACS example</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: In the Select JSP Template dialog, select New JSP File (html) and click Finish.
trans-unit.target: In the Select JSP Template dialog, select New JSP File (html) and click Finish.

trans-unit.source: When the index.jsp file opens in Eclipse, add in text to display Hello ACS World! within the existing element. Your updated content should appear as the following:
trans-unit.target: When the index.jsp file opens in Eclipse, add in text to display Hello ACS World! within the existing element. Your updated content should appear as the following:

trans-unit.source: Save index.jsp.
trans-unit.target: Save index.jsp.

trans-unit.source: In Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click MyACSHelloWorld, click Build Path, and then click Configure Build Path.
trans-unit.target: In Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click MyACSHelloWorld, click Build Path, and then click Configure Build Path.

trans-unit.source: In the Java Build Path dialog, click the Libraries tab.
trans-unit.target: In the Java Build Path dialog, click the Libraries tab.

trans-unit.source: Click Add Library.
trans-unit.target: Click Add Library.

trans-unit.source: Click Azure Access Control Services Filter (by MS Open Tech) and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Azure Access Control Services Filter (by MS Open Tech) and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Access Control Services Filter dialog is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Access Control Services Filter dialog is displayed.

trans-unit.source: (The Location field may have a different path, depending on where you installed Eclipse, and the version number could be different, depending on software updates.)
trans-unit.target: (The Location field may have a different path, depending on where you installed Eclipse, and the version number could be different, depending on software updates.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add ACS Filter library</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add ACS Filter library</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Using a browser opened to the Login Page Integration page of the Management Portal, copy the URL listed in the Option 1: Link to an ACS-hosted login page field and paste it into the ACS Authentication Endpoint field of the Eclipse dialog.
trans-unit.target: Using a browser opened to the Login Page Integration page of the Management Portal, copy the URL listed in the Option 1: Link to an ACS-hosted login page field and paste it into the ACS Authentication Endpoint field of the Eclipse dialog.

trans-unit.source: Using a browser opened to the Edit Relying Party Application page of the Management Portal, copy the URL listed in the Realm field and paste it into the Relying Party Realm field of the Eclipse dialog.
trans-unit.target: Using a browser opened to the Edit Relying Party Application page of the Management Portal, copy the URL listed in the Realm field and paste it into the Relying Party Realm field of the Eclipse dialog.

trans-unit.source: Within the Security section of the Eclipse dialog, if you want to use an existing certificate, click Browse, navigate to the certificate you want to use, select it, and click Open.
trans-unit.target: Within the Security section of the Eclipse dialog, if you want to use an existing certificate, click Browse, navigate to the certificate you want to use, select it, and click Open.

trans-unit.source: Or, if you want to create a new certificate, click New to display the New Certificate dialog, then specify the password, name of the .cer file, and name of the .pfx file for the new certificate.
trans-unit.target: Or, if you want to create a new certificate, click New to display the New Certificate dialog, then specify the password, name of the .cer file, and name of the .pfx file for the new certificate.

trans-unit.source: Check Embed the certificate in the WAR file.
trans-unit.target: Check Embed the certificate in the WAR file.

trans-unit.source: Embedding the certificate in this manner includes it in your deployment without requiring you to manually add it as a component.
trans-unit.target: Embedding the certificate in this manner includes it in your deployment without requiring you to manually add it as a component.

trans-unit.source: (If instead you must store your certificate externally from your WAR file, you could add the certificate as a role component and uncheck Embed the certificate in the WAR file.)
trans-unit.target: (If instead you must store your certificate externally from your WAR file, you could add the certificate as a role component and uncheck Embed the certificate in the WAR file.)

trans-unit.source: [Optional] Keep Require HTTPS connections checked.
trans-unit.target: [Optional] Keep Require HTTPS connections checked.

trans-unit.source: If you set this option, you'll need to access your application using the HTTPS protocol.
trans-unit.target: If you set this option, you'll need to access your application using the HTTPS protocol.

trans-unit.source: If you don't want to require HTTPS connections, uncheck this option.
trans-unit.target: If you don't want to require HTTPS connections, uncheck this option.

trans-unit.source: For a deployment to the compute emulator, your Azure ACS Filter settings will look similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: For a deployment to the compute emulator, your Azure ACS Filter settings will look similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure ACS Filter settings for a deployment to the compute emulator</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure ACS Filter settings for a deployment to the compute emulator</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Click Yes when presented with with a dialog box stating that a web.xml file will be created.
trans-unit.target: Click Yes when presented with with a dialog box stating that a web.xml file will be created.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to close the Java Build Path dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to close the Java Build Path dialog.

trans-unit.source: In Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click MyACSHelloWorld, click Azure, and then click Package for Azure.
trans-unit.target: In Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click MyACSHelloWorld, click Azure, and then click Package for Azure.

trans-unit.source: For Project name, type MyAzureACSProject and click Next.
trans-unit.target: For Project name, type MyAzureACSProject and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Select a JDK and application server.
trans-unit.target: Select a JDK and application server.

trans-unit.source: (These steps are covered in detail in the <linkText>Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse</linkText><title></title> tutorial).
trans-unit.target: (These steps are covered in detail in the <linkText>Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse</linkText><title></title> tutorial).

trans-unit.source: Click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Click the Run in Azure Emulator button.
trans-unit.target: Click the Run in Azure Emulator button.

trans-unit.source: After your Java web application starts in the compute emulator, close all instances of your browser (so that any current browser sessions do not interfere with your ACS login test).
trans-unit.target: After your Java web application starts in the compute emulator, close all instances of your browser (so that any current browser sessions do not interfere with your ACS login test).

trans-unit.source: Run your application by opening in your browser (or if you checked Require HTTPS connections). You should be prompted for a Windows Live ID login, then you should be taken to the return URL specified for your relying party application.
trans-unit.target: Run your application by opening in your browser (or if you checked Require HTTPS connections). You should be prompted for a Windows Live ID login, then you should be taken to the return URL specified for your relying party application.

trans-unit.source: When you have finished viewing your application, click the Reset Azure Emulator button.
trans-unit.target: When you have finished viewing your application, click the Reset Azure Emulator button.

trans-unit.source: To deploy to Azure, you'll need to change the relying party realm and return URL for your ACS namespace.
trans-unit.target: To deploy to Azure, you'll need to change the relying party realm and return URL for your ACS namespace.

trans-unit.source: Within the Azure Management Portal, in the Edit Relying Party Application page, modify Realm to be the URL of your deployed site.
trans-unit.target: Within the Azure Management Portal, in the Edit Relying Party Application page, modify Realm to be the URL of your deployed site.

trans-unit.source: Replace example with the DNS name you specified for your deployment.
trans-unit.target: Replace example with the DNS name you specified for your deployment.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Relying party realm for use in production</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Relying party realm for use in production</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Modify Return URL to be the URL of your application.
trans-unit.target: Modify Return URL to be the URL of your application.

trans-unit.source: Replace example with the DNS name you specified for your deployment.
trans-unit.target: Replace example with the DNS name you specified for your deployment.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Relying party return URL for use in production</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Relying party return URL for use in production</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Save to save your updated replying party realm and return URL changes.
trans-unit.target: Click Save to save your updated replying party realm and return URL changes.

trans-unit.source: Keep the Login Page Integration page open in your browser, you'll need to copy from it shortly.
trans-unit.target: Keep the Login Page Integration page open in your browser, you'll need to copy from it shortly.

trans-unit.source: In Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click MyACSHelloWorld, click Build Path, and then click Configure Build Path.
trans-unit.target: In Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click MyACSHelloWorld, click Build Path, and then click Configure Build Path.

trans-unit.source: Click the Libraries tab, click Azure Access Control Services Filter, and then click Edit.
trans-unit.target: Click the Libraries tab, click Azure Access Control Services Filter, and then click Edit.

trans-unit.source: Using a browser opened to the Login Page Integration page of the Management Portal, copy the URL listed in the Option 1: Link to an ACS-hosted login page field and paste it into the ACS Authentication Endpoint field of the Eclipse dialog.
trans-unit.target: Using a browser opened to the Login Page Integration page of the Management Portal, copy the URL listed in the Option 1: Link to an ACS-hosted login page field and paste it into the ACS Authentication Endpoint field of the Eclipse dialog.

trans-unit.source: Using a browser opened to the Edit Relying Party Application page of the Management Portal, copy the URL listed in the Realm field and paste it into the Relying Party Realm field of the Eclipse dialog.
trans-unit.target: Using a browser opened to the Edit Relying Party Application page of the Management Portal, copy the URL listed in the Realm field and paste it into the Relying Party Realm field of the Eclipse dialog.

trans-unit.source: Within the Security section of the Eclipse dialog, if you want to use an existing certificate, click Browse, navigate to the certificate you want to use, select it, and click Open.
trans-unit.target: Within the Security section of the Eclipse dialog, if you want to use an existing certificate, click Browse, navigate to the certificate you want to use, select it, and click Open.

trans-unit.source: Or, if you want to create a new certificate, click New to display the New Certificate dialog, then specify the password, name of the .cer file, and name of the .pfx file for the new certificate.
trans-unit.target: Or, if you want to create a new certificate, click New to display the New Certificate dialog, then specify the password, name of the .cer file, and name of the .pfx file for the new certificate.

trans-unit.source: Keep Embed the certificate in the WAR file checked, assuming you want to embed the certificate in the WAR file.
trans-unit.target: Keep Embed the certificate in the WAR file checked, assuming you want to embed the certificate in the WAR file.

trans-unit.source: [Optional] Keep Require HTTPS connections checked.
trans-unit.target: [Optional] Keep Require HTTPS connections checked.

trans-unit.source: If you set this option, you'll need to access your application using the HTTPS protocol.
trans-unit.target: If you set this option, you'll need to access your application using the HTTPS protocol.

trans-unit.source: If you don't want to require HTTPS connections, uncheck this option.
trans-unit.target: If you don't want to require HTTPS connections, uncheck this option.

trans-unit.source: For a deployment to Azure, your Azure ACS Filter settings will look similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: For a deployment to Azure, your Azure ACS Filter settings will look similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure ACS Filter settings for a production deployment</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure ACS Filter settings for a production deployment</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Finish to close the Edit Library dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish to close the Edit Library dialog.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to close the Properties for MyACSHelloWorld dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to close the Properties for MyACSHelloWorld dialog.

trans-unit.source: In Eclipse, click the Publish to Azure Cloud button.
trans-unit.target: In Eclipse, click the Publish to Azure Cloud button.

trans-unit.source: Respond to the prompts, similar as done in the To deploy your application to Azure section of the Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse topic.
trans-unit.target: Respond to the prompts, similar as done in the To deploy your application to Azure section of the Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse topic.

trans-unit.source: After your web application has been deployed, close any open browser sessions, run your web application, and you should be prompted to sign in with Windows Live ID credentials, followed by being sent to the return URL of your relying party application.
trans-unit.target: After your web application has been deployed, close any open browser sessions, run your web application, and you should be prompted to sign in with Windows Live ID credentials, followed by being sent to the return URL of your relying party application.

trans-unit.source: When you are done using your ACS Hello World application, remember to delete the deployment (you can learn how to delete a deployment in the <linkText>Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse</linkText><title></title> topic).
trans-unit.target: When you are done using your ACS Hello World application, remember to delete the deployment (you can learn how to delete a deployment in the <linkText>Creating a Hello World Application for Azure in Eclipse</linkText><title></title> topic).

trans-unit.source: For an examination of the Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) returned by ACS to your application, see <linkText>How to view SAML returned by the Azure Access Control Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For an examination of the Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) returned by ACS to your application, see <linkText>How to view SAML returned by the Azure Access Control Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To further explore ACS's functionality and to experiment with more sophisticated scenarios, see <linkText>Access Control Service 2.0</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To further explore ACS's functionality and to experiment with more sophisticated scenarios, see <linkText>Access Control Service 2.0</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Also, this example used the Embed the certificate in the WAR file option.
trans-unit.target: Also, this example used the Embed the certificate in the WAR file option.

trans-unit.source: This option makes it simple to deploy the certificate.
trans-unit.target: This option makes it simple to deploy the certificate.

trans-unit.source: If instead you want to keep your signing certificate separate from your WAR file, you can use the following technique:
trans-unit.target: If instead you want to keep your signing certificate separate from your WAR file, you can use the following technique:

trans-unit.source: Within the Security section of the Azure Access Control Services Filter dialog, type ${env.JAVA_HOME}/mycert.cer and uncheck Embed the certificate in the WAR file.
trans-unit.target: Within the Security section of the Azure Access Control Services Filter dialog, type ${env.JAVA_HOME}/mycert.cer and uncheck Embed the certificate in the WAR file.

trans-unit.source: (Adjust mycert.cer if your certificate file name is different.)
trans-unit.target: (Adjust mycert.cer if your certificate file name is different.)

trans-unit.source: Click Finish to close the dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click Finish to close the dialog.

trans-unit.source: Copy the certificate as a component in your deployment: In Eclipse's Project Explorer, expand MyAzureACSProject, right-click WorkerRole1, click Properties, expand Azure Role, and click Components.
trans-unit.target: Copy the certificate as a component in your deployment: In Eclipse's Project Explorer, expand MyAzureACSProject, right-click WorkerRole1, click Properties, expand Azure Role, and click Components.

trans-unit.source: Click Add.
trans-unit.target: Click Add.

trans-unit.source: Within the Add Component dialog:
trans-unit.target: Within the Add Component dialog:

trans-unit.source: In the Import section:
trans-unit.target: In the Import section:

trans-unit.source: Use the File button to navigate to the certificate you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Use the File button to navigate to the certificate you want to use.

trans-unit.source: For Method, select copy.
trans-unit.target: For Method, select copy.

trans-unit.source: For As Name, click on the text box and accept the default name.
trans-unit.target: For As Name, click on the text box and accept the default name.

trans-unit.source: In the Deploy section:
trans-unit.target: In the Deploy section:

trans-unit.source: For Method, select copy.
trans-unit.target: For Method, select copy.

trans-unit.source: For To directory, type %JAVA_HOME%.
trans-unit.target: For To directory, type %JAVA_HOME%.

trans-unit.source: Your Add Component dialog should look similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: Your Add Component dialog should look similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add certificate component</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add certificate component</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: At this point, your certificate would be included in your deployment.
trans-unit.target: At this point, your certificate would be included in your deployment.

trans-unit.source: Note that regardless of whether you embed the certificate in the WAR file or add it as a component to your deployment, you need to upload the certificate to your namespace as described in the <linkText>Upload a certificate to your ACS namespace</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: Note that regardless of whether you embed the certificate in the WAR file or add it as a component to your deployment, you need to upload the certificate to your namespace as described in the <linkText>Upload a certificate to your ACS namespace</linkText><title></title> section.
